# Operational and Technological Risk Oversight

In response to the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic in early 2020, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) implemented a series of measures to mitigate the impact of the pandemic on banking operations. These measures included requiring authorized institutions to review their business continuity plans and take appropriate preventative measures to protect the health of their employees and customers, as well as to maintain essential banking services. In addition, the HKMA reminded authorized institutions to strengthen communication with their employees and customers, prepare for potential confirmed cases at their premises, and develop business continuity plans to address more severe, yet possible, risk scenarios. The HKMA maintained close contact with the industry and requested authorized institutions to remain vigilant and regularly review their business continuity plans in light of the latest developments of the pandemic and the government’s social distancing measures.

Following a comprehensive review and extensive industry consultation on the “Cyber Resilience Assessment Framework,” the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) launched “Cyber Resilience Assessment Framework 2.0” in November, further enhancing the framework in line with the latest international practices in overseas cyber risk management. The “Cyber Resilience Assessment Framework” incorporates the latest international robust practices regarding cyber incident response and recovery. Regarding the “Professional Training Scheme” under the “Cyber Resilience Assessment Framework,” the scope of the qualification accreditation list has been expanded to include equivalent qualifications from major overseas regions. The HKMA has also made several recommendations to the Hong Kong Association of Banks (HKAB) to make the “Cyber Risk Information Sharing Platform” more user-friendly. “Cyber Resilience Assessment Framework 2.0” took effect on January 1, 2021.

# Smart Banking

Following rigorous testing and trials within the “FinTech Regulatory Sandbox,” all eight virtual banks licensed in 2019 have launched operations this year. These virtual banks leverage innovative technologies to provide a novel customer experience, such as utilizing big data analytics for credit assessment of SME loans to expedite the loan approval process. To enhance customer engagement and build brand loyalty, some virtual banks have also incorporated gamification elements into their services, including fixed deposit accounts and reward programs.

# Regulation of Liquidity and Market Risk

In April, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) introduced a series of measures to ensure the continued smooth functioning of the interbank market and the banking system during the epidemic. These measures included clarifying the operational details of the “HKMA Liquidity Facility” and launching a temporary US dollar liquidity facility, as well as reaffirming the flexibility for authorized institutions to utilize liquidity buffers under the regulatory framework. The HKMA also conducted exercises with authorized institutions to ensure they were prepared to deploy these measures when necessary.

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

香港繼續是具全球競爭力的國際金融中心。年內金管局採取多項措施，促進銀行及支付行業開發與應用金融科技。在新冠病毒疫情下年內快速支付系統「轉數快」交易量急增。

香港位處內地金融市場對外開放的要衝，能充分把握開放過程中的契機。憑藉世界級的市場基建以及「滬港通」、「深港通」與「債券通」，香港既是深受內地企業垂青的集資平台，亦是國際投資者進入增長迅速的內地市場的窗口。年內在促進粵港澳大灣區金融合作，尤其便利香港居民在大灣區內使用金融及銀行服務方面取得良好進展。

與此同時，金管局積極開拓新機遇，提升香港金融平台，包括資產及財富管理、企業財資中心，以及可持續金融範疇的競爭力。金管局亦加強市場推廣，向海外及內地持份者推廣香港的金融服務。在環球層面，金管局在多個區內及國際委員會擔當領導角色，充分凸顯香港在相關國際工作的專業知識及承擔。

# 概覽

為鞏固香港的亞洲金融科技樞紐地位，金管局繼續致力實施各項措施，促進銀行及支付行業開發與應用科技。年內的主要進展包括：
- 推動更廣泛使用快速支付系統「轉數快」；
- 促進銀行業實施開放應用程式介面（開放API）；
- 連接貿易融資平台「貿易聯動」與中國人民銀行（人民銀行）轄下的貿易金融區塊鏈平台，促進貿易融資數碼化；
- 研究央行數碼貨幣於跨境支付的應用；
- 探討「商業數據通」的技術可行性及研究新類型信貸評分模型，以助中小型企業（中小企）獲取融資；
- 公布旨在發展更具規模及更多元的合規科技生態圈的兩年計劃，進一步推動合規科技的應用；
- 加強培育人才；及
- 推進跨境金融科技合作。

金管局金融科技促進辦公室(FFO)與金管局各銀行部門聯手，在推動上述措施中發揮關鍵作用。

隨着主要金融市場指數開始加入內地在岸證券或增加其權重，流入人民幣資產的資金繼續加快步伐。香港得天獨厚，憑藉連繫內地資本市場的「滬港通」、「深港通」及「債券通」，在促進國際投資者增加人民幣資產配置方面發揮關鍵的作用。在2020年，「債券通」平均每日交易額增加82%，至約193億元人民幣。為完善「債券通」運作，金管局推出新措施，包括新設特別結算周期服務、延長交易時間及引入新安排，讓投資者在選擇銀行進行貨幣兌換與外幣對沖方面有較多彈性。繼「債券通」北向通取得成功，金管局又與人民銀行組成工作小組研究南向通的框架。

金管局亦繼續致力加強香港與粵港澳大灣區（大灣區）內地城市之間的金融配套措施。內地當局公布一系列政策措施，支持區內金融發展。於6月，人民銀行、金管局與澳門金融管理局（澳門金管局）聯合宣布決定實施跨境「理財通」。金管局一直與內地和本地當局以及業界緊密合作，制定有關實施細則。金管局亦就其他措施與內地當局保持聯繫，尋求為香港銀行擴大政策空間拓展更廣闊的跨境業務範疇。年內，香港繼續保持作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位。香港的人民幣即時支付結算(RTGS)系統平均每日交易額創出1.2萬億元人民幣的新高。

金管局積極開拓新機遇，提升香港金融平台競爭力。為促進香港基金業務的發展，金管局與政府及業界緊密合作，為基金在本地落戶締造更有利的稅務及監管環境。金管局亦投入大量工作，繼續提升香港作為區內綠色及可持續金融樞紐的地位。與此同時，金管局加強市場推廣，向海外及內地持份者推廣香港的金融服務。

在中央銀行領域，金管局在多個區內及國際委員會擔當領導角色。例如，金管局為巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）轄下政策及標準小組，以及東亞及太平洋地區中央銀行會議(EMEAP)轄下金融市場工作小組主席。金管局亦擔任金融穩定理事會轄下非銀行監察專家小組及金融創新網絡聯席主席，並領導探討基準過渡相關監管事項的小組。

香港金融基建的安全及有效運作，為香港的國際金融中心地位奠定穩固基礎。處理銀行同業交易的4個RTGS系統、債務工具中央結算系統（CMU系統）及香港交易資料儲存庫（香港儲存庫）在2020年達到100%的系統可供使用率，高於99.95%的目標水平。透過於內地兩個中央證券託管機構的帳戶，CMU系統繼續協助結算「債券通」北向通交易，以及替相關CMU系統成員持有內地債務證券。

轉數快使用量在2020年繼續增長。截至2020年底合共錄得690萬個登記，全年交易量較2019年上升兩倍。政府接受以轉數快繳費及更多商戶採用，是轉數快在個人對個人支付穩步增長以外，交易額錄得顯著增長的主要原因。

為確保本地零售支付業的整體安全及效率，金管局根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）指定及監察6個零售支付系統。金管局亦繼續監管18個儲值支付工具持牌人。

# 2020年回顧

# 轉數快

自2018年9月轉數快推出以來，已有35間銀行及12間儲值支付工具營運商加入，其中在2020年增加了5間銀行及1間儲值支付工具營運商。轉數快使用量亦穩步增長。截至12月31日，轉數快共錄得690萬個登記（圖1）。為方便市民收取由機構發出的款項，轉數快於12月6日起新增以香港身份證號碼作帳戶識別代號。引入這項功能後不足1個月已錄得超過110,000個登記。這項新功能並非用於個人對個人轉帳，只供已有收款人身份證號碼的機構發放款項（例如發放薪酬）之用。由於每名市民的身份證號碼都是獨一無二，市民利用香港身份證號碼作為帳戶識別代號，即使不提供銀行帳戶號碼都能夠確保準確收取款項。

圖 1 轉數快帳戶登記數目

新冠病毒疫情及保持社交距離措施為使用電子支付服務帶來新動力。年內轉數快交易量增長尤其迅速（圖2），於2020年12月的平均每日交易量達505,000宗即時交易（涉及52億港元及9,500萬元人民幣），相當於2019年12月168,000宗的3倍，更是2018年10月轉數快推出首月的10倍。轉數快使用量增加，亦受惠於應用範圍逐步擴大，由最初主要用作個人對個人支付，逐步擴展至繳付帳單（包括政府帳單）、零售及商業支付。

圖 2 港元即時支付平均每日交易數字

金管局與多個政府部門及銀行業一直合作，將轉數快的應用範圍由個人對個人支付，擴展至繳付帳單及其他商戶支付。政府於2019年11月起接受以轉數快繳付帳單，以推廣使用轉數快及便利市民。市民以支援轉數快的手機銀行或電子錢包掃描印於帳單上的二維碼，即可輕鬆繳付稅款、差餉及地租、水費及政府發出的一般繳費單。截至2020年12月經轉數快繳付政府帳單的交易達180萬宗，涉及22億港元。繼繳付政府帳單服務成功推出後，再有4個政府部門由2020年12月21日起接受在指定繳費櫃枱及自助服務機以轉數快二維碼繳費。政府亦正在探討於網上採用轉數快付款的安排。

另一正面的發展是越來越多大小商戶採用轉數快以加強業務營運。支付商戶的交易在2020年12月急增至平均每日100,000宗，較2019年12月增加38倍轉數快普遍用作繳付帳單、應用程式內直接扣帳，以及進行其他網上購物。電子錢包日益普及，亦帶動了以轉數快為帳戶增值的交易量顯著增長。2020年12月平均每日增值的交易量，是2019年12月的7倍。

為加強市民對轉數快的認識，金管局製作各類教育及宣傳資料，包括電視廣告及在社交媒體平台提供一系列精明使用錦囊。金管局亦舉辦中學生Whatsapp Stickers設計比賽，增加他們對電子支付的認識。此外，金管局向多個慈善團體及街市營運商推廣使用轉數快收付款項。多間參與轉數快的銀行及儲值支付工具營運商亦推出宣傳活動，包括提供優惠，吸引客戶登記及利用轉數快轉帳及支付帳單。在2020年的成果上，金管局在2021年初與銀行及儲值支付工具營運商合作，推廣透過轉數快以電子方式派利是。一方面金管局推出宣傳活動，另一方面銀行及儲值支付工具營運商則提供優惠，鼓勵客戶以電子方式派利是，既環保又有助抗疫。

# 開放應用程式介面

金管局繼續促進銀行業按照開放API框架研發及提供開放API。該框架分4個階段實施，銀行已推出第一及第二階段開放API，並以這些開放API與第三方服務提供者合作，開拓各項創新服務，提升客戶體驗。另一方面，金管局就實施第三及第四階段開放API進行調查研究，並於11月刊發小冊子，刊載調查結果。

# 貿易聯動

為使進出口商獲得更方便的貿易融資服務，金管局於年內展開概念驗證研究，探討連接「貿易聯動」與人民銀行轄下的貿易金融區塊鏈平台。該研究的首階段於年內第4季完成，並隨後開始試行。香港和內地銀行已用該連接成功完成多項跨境貿易融資交易。

# 跨境支付

央行數碼貨幣方面，金管局與泰國中央銀行繼續進行聯合研究，探討央行數碼貨幣於跨境支付的應用藉此促進香港與泰國兩地銀行之間港元和泰銖的外匯交易同步交收。雙方完成第一階段研究，並於1月發表聯合報告闡述主要研究結果；另亦開發以區塊鏈為基礎的跨境走廊網絡原型，致力提高跨境支付的效率及降低成本。項目第二階段已展開，旨在探討跨境貿易結算及資本市場交易的商業應用案例。其他央行亦對項目深感興趣。國際結算銀行、阿拉伯聯合酋長國中央銀行和人民銀行數字貨幣研究所於2021年初宣布參與項目。

# Hong Kong's status as an international financial center.

Hong Kong continues to be a globally competitive international financial center. Throughout the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority took multiple measures to promote the development and application of financial technology in the banking and payment industries. Amidst the COVID-19 pandemic, transaction volume for the Faster Payment System, “FPS,” surged rapidly this year.

Hong Kong is strategically located at the forefront of China’s financial market opening-up, allowing it to fully capitalize on the opportunities arising from this process. With world-class market infrastructure and schemes like Stock Connect (Shanghai-Hong Kong and Shenzhen-Hong Kong) and Bond Connect, Hong Kong is both a preferred fundraising platform for Mainland enterprises and a gateway for international investors to access the rapidly growing Mainland market. Significant progress has been made this year in promoting financial cooperation within the Greater Bay Area, particularly in facilitating Hong Kong residents’ access to financial and banking services within the region.

At the same time, the HKMA is actively exploring new opportunities and enhancing Hong Kong’s financial platform, including its competitiveness in asset and wealth management, corporate finance, and sustainable finance. The HKMA is also strengthening market promotion, showcasing Hong Kong’s financial services to stakeholders both overseas and in Mainland China. On the global stage, the HKMA plays a leading role in various regional and international committees, fully demonstrating Hong Kong’s expertise and commitment in related international work.

# Overview

To consolidate Hong Kong’s position as a leading Asian financial technology hub, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to actively implement various measures to promote the development and application of technology within the banking and payments industries. Key progress made this year includes:
- Promoting wider adoption of the Faster Payment System “Faster Payments System”;
- Facilitating the implementation of Open Application Programming Interfaces (Open APIs) in the banking sector;
- Connecting the Trade Finance Platform “e-Trade Connect” with the trade finance blockchain platform under the People’s Bank of China (PBOC), to promote the digitalization of trade finance;
- Researching the application of Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC) in cross-border payments;
- Exploring the technical feasibility of “Commercial Data Exchange” and researching new credit scoring models to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) access financing;
- Announcing a two-year plan to develop a larger and more diverse RegTech ecosystem, further promoting the application of RegTech;
- Strengthening talent cultivation; and
- Advancing cross-border FinTech collaboration.

The Financial Technology Promotion Office (FFO) of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, working in conjunction with various departments within the HKMA, played a key role in promoting the aforementioned measures.

As major financial market indices begin to include mainland China’s onshore securities or increase their weighting, the inflow of funds into RMB-denominated assets continues to accelerate. Hong Kong is uniquely positioned to play a key role in facilitating increased allocation to RMB assets by international investors, thanks to its connectivity to mainland China’s capital markets through schemes such as Stock Connect (Shanghai-Hong Kong), Stock Connect (Shenzhen-Hong Kong), and Bond Connect. In 2020, the average daily turnover of Bond Connect increased by 82% to approximately RMB 19.3 billion. To refine the operation of Bond Connect, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has launched new measures, including the introduction of a new special settlement cycle service, extended trading hours, and new arrangements to provide investors with greater flexibility in choosing banks for currency exchange and foreign exchange hedging. Following the success of the Northbound Bond Connect, the HKMA has again formed a working group with the People’s Bank of China to study the framework for Southbound Bond Connect.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to enhance financial facilitation measures between Hong Kong and Mainland cities in the Greater Bay Area (GBA). Mainland authorities have announced a series of policy measures to support financial development within the region. In June, the People’s Bank of China, the HKMA, and the Monetary Authority of Macao jointly announced a decision to implement the Cross-Boundary Wealth Management Connect. The HKMA has been working closely with Mainland and local authorities, as well as industry participants, to formulate the detailed implementation rules. The HKMA is also maintaining communication with Mainland authorities regarding other measures, seeking to expand the policy space for Hong Kong banks to broaden the scope of their cross-border business. Throughout the year, Hong Kong has continued to maintain its position as a global offshore RMB business hub. The average daily transaction volume of Hong Kong’s RMB Real-Time Gross Settlement (RTGS) system reached a new high of RMB 1.2 trillion.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is actively exploring new opportunities and enhancing the competitiveness of Hong Kong’s financial platform. To promote the development of the fund industry in Hong Kong, the HKMA is working closely with the Government and industry stakeholders to create a more favorable tax and regulatory environment for funds to establish a presence locally. The HKMA is also dedicating significant effort to further strengthen Hong Kong’s position as a regional hub for green and sustainable finance. At the same time, the HKMA is intensifying its marketing efforts to promote Hong Kong’s financial services to stakeholders both overseas and in Mainland China.

In the realm of central banking, the HKMA plays a leading role in various areas and on international committees. For example, the HKMA chairs the Policy and Standards Group under the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS), as well as the Financial Market Workstream under the East Asia and Pacific Central Banks (EMEAP). The HKMA also serves as a joint chair of the Non-bank Financial Intermediation Supervision Experts Group and the Financial Innovation Network under the Financial Stability Board, and leads a group exploring regulatory matters related to benchmark transitions.

The safe and effective operation of Hong Kong’s financial infrastructure underpins its status as an international financial center. The four Real-Time Gross Settlement (RTGS) systems handling interbank transactions, the Central Money Markets Unit (CMU) system, and the Hong Kong Securities Clearing and Settlement System (Hong Kong Securities Depository) all achieved 100% system availability in 2020, exceeding the target level of 99.95%. Through accounts maintained with two central securities depositories on the Mainland, the CMU system continued to facilitate the settlement of northbound trading under the Bond Connect scheme, as well as holding Mainland debt securities on behalf of relevant CMU system members.

The number of registered users for Faster Payments System (FPS) continued to grow in 2020. A total of 6.9 million registrations were recorded by the end of 2020, with transaction volume more than doubling compared to 2019. Government acceptance of FPS for fee payments and increased adoption by merchants were key reasons for the significant growth in transaction value, in addition to the steady growth of person-to-person payments.

To ensure the overall safety and efficiency of the local retail payment industry, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) designates and supervises six retail payment systems under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (the “Payment Ordinance”). The HKMA also continues to regulate 18 licensed stored value facility operators.

## 2020 Retrospective

# Hong Kong's position as an Asian FinTech hub.

# Quick-witted.

Since its launch in September 2018, 35 banks and 12 stored value facility operators have joined Faster Payment System (FPS). In 2020 alone, 5 banks and 1 stored value facility operator were added. FPS usage has also been steadily increasing. As of December 31st, a total of 6.9 million registrations had been recorded (Figure 1). To facilitate the public in receiving funds from organizations, FPS added the use of Hong Kong Identity Card numbers as account identifiers starting December 6th. Within less than a month of introducing this function, over 110,000 registrations were recorded. This new function is not for person-to-person transfers; it is solely for organizations to disburse funds to recipients whose identity card numbers are already known (e.g., salary payments). As each citizen’s identity card number is unique, using it as an account identifier ensures accurate receipt of funds even without providing a bank account number.

Figure 1: Number of Fast Transfer Account Registrations

The COVID-19 pandemic and social distancing measures have provided new impetus for the use of electronic payment services. The volume of FPS (Faster Payment System) transactions grew particularly rapidly within the year (Figure 2), reaching an average of 505,000 daily transactions in December 2020 (involving HK$5.2 billion and RMB 95 million), three times the 168,000 transactions in December 2019, and ten times the figure for the first month of FPS launch in October 2018. The increased usage of FPS has also benefited from the gradual expansion of its applications, from initially being used mainly for person-to-person payments to progressively including bill payments (including government bills), retail and commercial payments.

Figure 2: Average Daily Transaction Numbers for Hong Kong Dollar Instant Payments

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has been collaborating with various government departments and the banking sector to expand the application of Faster Payment System (FPS) from person-to-person payments to bill payments and other merchant payments. The government began accepting FPS for bill payments in November 2019 to promote the use of FPS and provide convenience to the public. Citizens can easily pay taxes, rates and government rent, water charges, and general government demand notes by scanning the QR codes printed on the bills using their FPS-enabled mobile banking apps or e-wallets. As of December 2020, there were 1.8 million transactions for government bill payments made via FPS, involving HK$2.2 billion. Following the successful launch of the government bill payment service, four more government departments began accepting FPS QR code payments at designated counter services and self-service kiosks from December 21, 2020. The government is also exploring arrangements for adopting FPS for online payments.

Another positive development is the increasing adoption of Faster Payment System (FPS) by businesses of all sizes to enhance their operations. Transactions at merchant payment points surged to an average of 100,000 per day in December 2020, a 38-fold increase compared to December 2019. FPS is commonly used for bill payments, direct debit within applications, and other online shopping. The growing popularity of e-wallets has also driven a significant increase in transactions for topping up accounts via FPS. The average daily top-up transaction volume in December 2020 was seven times that of December 2019.

To enhance public understanding of Faster Payment System (FPS), the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has produced a variety of educational and promotional materials, including television advertisements and a series of tips on using FPS wisely via social media platforms. The HKMA also organized a WhatsApp sticker design competition for secondary school students to increase their awareness of electronic payments. In addition, the HKMA has promoted the use of FPS for receiving payments to various charitable organizations and wet market operators. Many banks and stored value facility operators participating in FPS have also launched promotional campaigns, including offering incentives, to attract customers to register and use FPS for fund transfers and bill payments. Building on the success in 2020, the HKMA collaborated with banks and stored value facility operators in early 2021 to promote the electronic distribution of "lai see" (red packets) via FPS. While the HKMA launched promotional activities, banks and stored value facility operators offered incentives to encourage customers to distribute "lai see" electronically, which is both environmentally friendly and helps combat the epidemic.

# Open Application Interface

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to promote the banking sector’s development and provision of open application programming interfaces (APIs) in accordance with the Open API Framework. The framework is being implemented in four phases, with banks having already launched open APIs for the first and second phases and collaborating with third-party service providers using these APIs to develop a variety of innovative services and enhance customer experience. On the other hand, the HKMA is conducting research on the implementation of open APIs for the third and fourth phases and published a booklet in November detailing the survey results.

# Trade linkage.

To provide importers and exporters with more convenient trade finance services, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority initiated a concept proof-of-concept study this year to explore the connection between “TradeConnect” and the trade finance blockchain platform under the People’s Bank of China. The first phase of the study was completed in the fourth quarter of this year and pilot testing has since begun. Banks in Hong Kong and Mainland China have already successfully completed a number of cross-border trade finance transactions using this connection.

# Cross-border payment

Regarding central bank digital currencies, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Bank of Thailand continue to conduct joint research exploring the application of central bank digital currencies in cross-border payments, thereby facilitating the simultaneous settlement of Hong Kong dollar and Thai baht foreign exchange transactions between banks in Hong Kong and Thailand. The two sides have completed the first phase of research and published a joint report in January outlining the main research findings; they have also developed a prototype cross-border corridor network based on blockchain technology, striving to improve the efficiency and reduce the cost of cross-border payments. The second phase of the project has commenced, aiming to explore commercial use cases for cross-border trade settlement and capital market transactions. Other central banks have also expressed strong interest in the project. The Bank for International Settlements, the Central Bank of the UAE, and the Digital Currency Institute of the People's Bank of China announced their participation in the project in early 2021.

# 儲備管理

2020年是峰迴路轉的一年，新冠病毒疫情為全球經濟帶來前所未有的挑戰。資產市場於第1 季經歷了大幅調整和震盪後，在主要央行推出超寬鬆的貨幣政策及各地政府實施大規模的財政紓困措施帶動下，得以迅速反彈。由於主要央行大幅下調基準利率並重啟量化寬鬆措施，令國債收益率顯著下跌、債券價格上升。在此投資環境下，外匯基金在2020 年錄得2,358 億港元的投資收入，回報率為5.3%。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。金管局根據財政司司長轉授的權力及轉授權力的條款，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合架構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：
(a) 保障資本；
(b) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(c) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(d) 在符合上述(a)至(c)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合結構及目標資產配置中反映。

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員國的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產配置於較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權（包括基建）及房地產。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的市值上限為外匯基金累計盈餘的三分之一，以及未來基金存款與外匯基金附屬公司存款中與長期增長組合掛鈎部分的總和。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，一直持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎，但未來基金屬主要個別例子。未來基金存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的表現掛鈎，實際利率視乎組合比重而定。未來基金在投資組合與長期增長組合的比重約為40：60。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產配置及戰略性資產配置作基礎。策略性資產配置，會以投資基準方式反映，亦即外匯基金為達到投資目標而可作出的長線資產配置。外匯基金以策略性配置作為指引，透過戰略性的資產配置，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際配置往往會與基準配置（亦即策略性配置）有所偏離，而實際與基準配置之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及循跡誤差限額，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產配置及定出戰略性偏離的容許範圍。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的容許範圍內管理倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 投資管理

# 直接投資

金管局的外匯基金投資辦公室專責投資及相關風險管理職能。該辦公室職員負責直接管理外匯基金約72%的投資，包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分投資組合包括不同的環球定息市場投資，並透過衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約28%的資產，包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產。僱用外聘投資經理的目的是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資專才為外匯基金投資，獲取可持續回報，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化及互補的投資方式，以及汲取市場心得與專門的投資知識。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

# 風險管理及監察

投資環境越趨複雜，風險管理的重要性不言而喻。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂下嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並設立嚴謹的風險監察及合規制度。金管局為投資相關活動設有三重防線以確保有效的風險管理及監察。金管局亦定期監察主要投資風險類別（包括信用、市場、流動性及業務操作風險），並已加強風險管理程序以配合外匯基金的多元化投資。

# 負責任投資

金管局支持負責任投資，將環境、社會及管治(ESG)因素併入外匯基金的公開市場及私募市場的投資管理過程。

金管局訂有一套原則，以評估外匯基金投資項目的ESG風險與機會。就外聘投資經理所管理的資產組合而言，金管局透過獲委任的投資經理執行負責任投資。在甄選、委任及監察外聘投資經理的過程中，金管局會評估其落實ESG的不同範疇，包括ESG管治方面的組織架構、ESG標準及政策、將ESG因素併入投資程序中的情況，以及管理督導的業務活動，即代理投票和與投資組合公司的溝通（例如與投資組合公司管理層商討ESG的事宜）。為彰顯對負責任投資的重視，金管局透過外聘投資經理在管理督導方面扮演的角色，推動更完善的ESG做法。負責管理金管局的香港股票組合及中國內地股票主動投資管理組合的外聘投資經理，須承諾遵守證券及期貨事務監察委員會頒布的《負責任的擁有權原則》，若未能遵守則須作出解釋。至於負責管理已發展市場股票組合的外聘投資經理則需恪守國際公認的ESG標準。此外，金管局又展開聘任後監察計劃，以審視外聘投資經理的代理投票及與投資組合公司溝通的落實概況。

由金管局內部人員負責管理的定息投資組合，亦將ESG因素融入債券投資的信用風險分析中。藉著擴大ESG數據來源以及在量化評估中提高ESG因素的權重，加強相關的分析。

至於在公開市場的ESG投資，金管局自2015年起投資於綠色、社會責任及可持續債券（ESG債券），是這個市場的早期投資者之一。此外，金管局亦參與國際金融公司的「聯合貸款組合管理計劃」，而其投資對象聚焦於新興市場的可持續發展項目。在2020年，適逢市場供應增加，金管局增加ESG債券的投資。展望未來，金管局將繼續透過直接投資或持有ESG債券基金等方式，壯大其ESG債券組合。此外，金管局將透過採納ESG股票指數作為被動投資組合的投資基準，推動外聘投資經理建立以ESG為主題的股票投資方針。金管局在未來幾年將會繼續留意以ESG為主題的投資機會，例如主動式的ESG投資組合及低碳為題的投資工具。

私募市場投資方面，金管局在盡職審查過程中檢視專責合夥人的ESG政策及具體措施。金管局的長期增長組合積極投資於具備可持續特點的項目，包括可再生能源基建，而在房地產投資組合亦有吸納具有綠色及可持續特點的倉庫及其他建築物。金管局將在未來繼續物色具備可持續特點的項目，並在房地產投資方面將綠色認證列入為重要考慮因素。金管局與專責合夥人舉行年度ESG工作坊，就良好的ESG作業手法交流意見及經驗。在11月舉行的ESG工作坊上，一眾專責合夥人就新冠病毒疫情對其投資組合公司及ESG投資發展所造成的影響交換意見。為提高私募市場投資的ESG透明度，金管局已要求專責合夥人提供有關其投資項目的ESG資訊，例如氣候變化風險等，以便監察。

金管局往後仍會密切觀察ESG標準的發展，評估如何將有關標準進一步融入投資程序，當中包括與理念相近的投資者及國際組織互動合作。金管局作為聯合國支持的《負責任投資原則》的簽署人之一，肩負作為全球倡導者的責任，日後將會參與制定ESG最佳作業手法，並推動其他投資者採納負責任的投資方法。金管局亦是非牟利機構 FCLTGlobal 的成員，該機構旨在透過舉辦工作坊及研究，鼓勵以長遠目標為本的業務及投資決策。金管局亦有參與「氣候相關財務資訊披露工作小組」，並為「央行與監管機構綠色金融網絡」的成員。此外，金管局籌辦講座及積極參與投資業界舉辦的活動，分享及推廣有關ESG投資的理念。

# Inventory Management

2020 was a year of dramatic twists and turns, as the COVID-19 pandemic brought unprecedented challenges to the global economy. After a sharp correction and volatility in asset markets during the first quarter, they rebounded quickly, driven by ultra-loose monetary policies implemented by major central banks and large-scale fiscal relief measures enacted by governments worldwide. Significant cuts to benchmark interest rates by major central banks, coupled with the resumption of quantitative easing, led to a marked decline in government bond yields and a rise in bond prices. In this investment environment, the Exchange Fund recorded investment income of HK$235.8 billion in 2020, representing an investment return of 5.3%.

# Exchange Stabilization Fund

According to the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary objective of the Exchange Fund is to influence the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar, directly or indirectly. It may also be used to maintain the stability and integrity of the monetary and financial system in Hong Kong, thereby preserving Hong Kong’s position as an international financial centre. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is accountable to the Financial Secretary for the operation and investment management of the Exchange Fund, in accordance with the powers delegated to it and the provisions for further delegation by the Financial Secretary.

# Management of the Exchange Fund

# Investment Objectives and Portfolio Structure

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee has established the following investment objectives for the Exchange Fund:
(a) to preserve capital;
(b) to ensure that the monetary base is at all times fully backed by highly liquid US dollar assets;
(c) to ensure sufficient liquidity is maintained to support monetary and financial stability; and
(d) to seek to maximize investment returns, consistent with the above objectives (a) to (c), in order to safeguard the long-term purchasing power of the Fund.

These objectives comprehensively address the statutory purposes of the Exchange Fund and are reflected in the Fund’s portfolio structure and target asset allocation.

The Exchange Fund is broadly divided into two main portfolios: the Support Portfolio and the Investment Portfolio. The Support Portfolio holds highly liquid US dollar assets, providing full backing for the monetary base in accordance with the provisions of the currency board system. The Investment Portfolio primarily invests in the debt and equity markets of member economies of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, with the aim of preserving the value and long-term purchasing power of the assets.

To better manage risks and enhance long-term returns, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is prudently and gradually diversifying the asset allocation of part of the Exchange Fund into a wider range of asset classes, including emerging markets and Mainland bonds and equities, private equity (including infrastructure), and real estate. Emerging markets and Mainland bonds and equities are held by the investment portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held by the Long-Term Growth Portfolio. The market value of the Long-Term Growth Portfolio is capped at one-third of the Exchange Fund’s accumulated surplus, plus the total of the portion of future fund deposits and deposits of the Exchange Fund’s subsidiaries that are linked to the Long-Term Growth Portfolio.

The Strategic Asset Portfolio was established in 2007 and has consistently held shares in Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited purchased by the Exchange Fund for strategic purposes. Due to the unique nature of this portfolio, its performance is not included in the assessment of the Exchange Fund’s investment performance.

# Regarding deposits in the Exchange Fund.

The Exchange Fund accepts deposits from fiscal reserves, government funds, and statutory organizations from time to time, with interest rates generally linked to the performance of its investment portfolio. However, the Future Fund is a primary individual example. The interest rate on deposits in the Future Fund is linked to the performance of both the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio, with the actual rate depending on the weighting of the portfolios. The Future Fund has an approximate 40:60 weighting between the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio.

# Investment Process

The Exchange Fund’s investment process is based on strategic asset allocation and tactical asset allocation. Strategic asset allocation is expressed as a benchmark, representing the long-term asset mix the Exchange Fund may adopt to achieve its investment objectives. The Exchange Fund uses strategic allocation as a guide and employs tactical asset allocation to seek returns exceeding the benchmark. Consequently, the actual allocation often deviates from the benchmark allocation (i.e., the strategic allocation), and the difference between the actual and benchmark allocations is known as “tactical deviation.” The Financial Secretary, after consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, sets the investment benchmark and tracking error limits. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is authorized to determine the tactical asset allocation and define the permissible range for tactical deviation. Portfolio managers can manage their positions within the permissible range of tactical deviation to profit from short-term market fluctuations.

# Investment Management

# Direct investment

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s (HKMA) Investment Office is responsible for investment and related risk management functions of the Exchange Fund. Staff of the office directly manage approximately 72% of the Exchange Fund’s investments, including the supporting portfolio and part of the investment portfolio. This portion of the investment portfolio includes investments in various global fixed income markets and implements the Exchange Fund’s macro risk management strategies through the use of derivatives.

# External Investment Manager

In addition to managing assets through internal staff, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority also employs external investment managers responsible for managing approximately 28% of the Exchange Fund’s assets, including all listed equity portfolios and other special assets. The purpose of employing external investment managers is to leverage the best professional investment expertise available in the market for Exchange Fund investments, to achieve sustainable returns, and to allow the Exchange Fund to benefit from diversified and complementary investment approaches, as well as to gain market insights and specialized investment knowledge.

Expenses related to hiring external investment managers include fund management and custody fees, transaction costs, withholding taxes, and other taxes. These expenses are primarily subject to market factors and vary annually.

# Risk Management and Oversight

The investment environment is becoming increasingly complex, and the importance of risk management is self-evident. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has established stringent control measures and investment guidelines for both internally and externally managed investment portfolios, along with rigorous risk monitoring and compliance systems. The HKMA employs a three-line-of-defense model for investment-related activities to ensure effective risk management and oversight. The HKMA also regularly monitors major categories of investment risk – including credit, market, liquidity, and operational risk – and has enhanced risk management procedures to accommodate the diversification of the Exchange Fund’s investments.

# Responsible Investment

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority supports responsible investment and integrates environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors into the investment management processes for the Exchange Fund’s public and private market investments.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has established a set of principles to assess the ESG risks and opportunities of its Exchange Fund investment projects. With respect to assets managed by external investment managers, the HKMA implements responsible investment through the managers it appoints. Throughout the selection, appointment, and monitoring of external investment managers, the HKMA assesses their implementation of various ESG aspects, including the organizational structure for ESG governance, ESG standards and policies, the integration of ESG factors into investment processes, and stewardship activities such as proxy voting and engagement with investee companies (for example, discussing ESG matters with the management of investee companies). To demonstrate its commitment to responsible investment, the HKMA promotes improved ESG practices through the stewardship role played by external investment managers. External investment managers responsible for managing the HKMA’s Hong Kong equity portfolio and the actively managed China A-share portfolio are required to commit to adhering to the Securities and Futures Commission’s “Principles of Responsible Ownership” and to provide explanations for any non-compliance. External investment managers responsible for managing emerging market equity portfolios are required to adhere to internationally recognized ESG standards. In addition, the HKMA conducts post-appointment monitoring to review the implementation of proxy voting and engagement with investee companies by external investment managers.

Fixed-income investment portfolios managed by internal staff at the HKMA also incorporate ESG factors into the credit risk analysis of bond investments. This is achieved by expanding the sources of ESG data and increasing the weighting of ESG factors in quantitative assessments, thereby strengthening the related analysis.

Regarding ESG investment in the public market, the HKMA has been investing in green, social responsibility, and sustainability bonds (ESG bonds) since 2015, making it one of the early investors in this market. In addition, the HKMA participates in the “Joint Loan Portfolio Management Program” of international financial institutions, with its investments focused on sustainable development projects in emerging markets. In 2020, coinciding with an increase in market supply, the HKMA increased its investment in ESG bonds. Looking ahead, the HKMA will continue to expand its ESG bond portfolio through direct investment or by holding ESG bond funds. Furthermore, the HKMA will promote externally appointed investment managers to establish ESG-themed equity investment strategies by adopting ESG stock indices as the investment benchmark for its passive investment portfolios. The HKMA will continue to monitor ESG-themed investment opportunities in the coming years, such as active ESG portfolios and low-carbon investment instruments.

In the private market investment arena, the HKMA reviews the ESG policies and specific measures of dedicated partners during the due diligence process. The HKMA’s long-term growth portfolio actively invests in projects with sustainable characteristics, including renewable energy infrastructure, and its real estate portfolio also incorporates warehouses and other buildings with green and sustainable features. The HKMA will continue to seek out projects with sustainable characteristics in the future, and will include green certifications as an important consideration in real estate investments. The HKMA holds annual ESG workshops with dedicated partners to exchange views and experiences on sound ESG practices. At the ESG workshop held in November, dedicated partners exchanged views on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their portfolio companies and the development of ESG investing. To enhance ESG transparency in private market investments, the HKMA has requested dedicated partners to provide ESG information regarding their investments, such as climate change risks, for monitoring purposes.

The HKMA will continue to closely monitor the development of ESG standards and assess how to further integrate them into its investment processes, including interacting and cooperating with like-minded investors and international organizations. As a signatory to the UN-supported Principles for Responsible Investment, the HKMA bears the responsibility of being a global advocate and will participate in the formulation of ESG best practices, and promote the adoption of responsible investment approaches by other investors. The HKMA is also a member of the non-profit organization FCLTGlobal, which aims to encourage long-term oriented business and investment decisions through workshops and research. The HKMA also participates in the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures and is a member of the Network for Greening the Financial System. In addition, the HKMA organizes seminars and actively participates in events hosted by the investment industry to share and promote the concepts of ESG investing.

Please refer to the chapter on “Institutional Social Responsibility” for details regarding the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s responsible investment policy framework.

## 2020 Financial Markets

Supported by the easing of monetary and fiscal policies introduced in response to the significant challenges posed to the global economy by the COVID-19 pandemic, global financial markets rose to high levels at the end of the year. After a significant correction and volatility in the first quarter, global stock markets rebounded rapidly, with major markets recording double-digit growth. The US S&P 500 Index rose by 16%, making it the best-performing stock index among the seven major industrial nations in 2020.

In the bond market, yields on major developed-country bonds continued to come under pressure after a significant decline in the first quarter. The yield on 10-year US Treasury bonds fell by approximately 100 basis points from 1.9% at the beginning of the year to 0.9% at year-end. Due to the sharp rise in major sovereign bond prices, 2020 saw very substantial valuation gains from the bond market.

In the currency market, declining U.S. interest rates led to a narrowing of interest rate differentials, causing the dollar to weaken against major currencies. This trend was even more pronounced in the second half of 2020, with the euro and the renminbi appreciating approximately 9.0% and 6.5% against the dollar, respectively.

# 金管局資訊中心

金管局資訊中心設於國際金融中心2期55樓，向公眾介紹金管局工作及提高公眾對貨幣與銀行業事宜的了解。資訊中心分為展覽館及圖書館兩部分。展覽館以互動方式介紹金管局的工作，以及香港貨幣與銀行業的發展；另備資料與展品，供研究香港貨幣、銀行業與金融事務。毗鄰展覽館的圖書館收藏超過26,000本書籍、期刊及其他刊物，以供研究香港貨幣、銀行業、金融和中央銀行事務等課題。圖書館亦備存《銀行業條例》第20條規定的「認可機構及本地代表辦事處紀錄冊」及「認可機構證券業務員工紀錄冊」。

金管局資訊中心憑藉其精心設計及獨樹一格的氛圍，從全球各地千多名參賽者中脫穎而出，成為「2020年MUSE DESIGN AWARDS」室內設計組別白金獎的得獎者之一。

資訊中心善用在2020年因應新冠病毒疫情暫停開放的時機，優化了「政策」展區的設施。該展區闡述金管局的工作，並介紹相關的金融概念。有關優化措施是因應訪客意見而作出，使互動設施更易使用、更富趣味及更耐用，令參觀過程更有樂趣。

資訊中心「政策」展區的互動設施完成優化工程。

資訊中心的展覽館部分介紹金管局的工作及香港貨幣與銀行業的發展。

為確保公眾人士不論種族都能平等地享用資訊中心的設施，中心制定程序，為有需要的訪客及致電中心熱線查詢的人士提供傳譯服務。

資訊中心的開放及服務時間因疫情持續而受到影響。為保障公眾安全及維持高水平的衛生環境，年內資訊中心實施特別開放安排及防疫措施，並加強清潔及消毒，設施及展品更定期以長效殺菌塗層消毒。

# 公眾及消費者教育

為與社區保持聯繫及增進市民對金管局工作的認識，金管局在2020年舉辦了一場網上公眾教育講座，吸引1,600多名來自61間中學的師生參加。講座內容涵蓋金管局工作簡介、聯繫匯率制度、香港鈔票、保障個人數碼鎖匙及存款保障計劃。教育講座自1998年推出以來，首次以網上形式舉行，至今已有超過61,000名師生參與。

超過1,600名來自61間中學的師生參加金管局網上公眾教育講座。

金管局教育公眾做個精明及負責任的金融服務消費者，並就此與公眾保持聯繫。相關教育工作的其中一個重點繼續是「保護個人數碼鎖匙」，年內金管局製作了一系列短片，呼籲市民不論何時何地都要妥善保管財務帳戶及個人資料。鑑於新冠病毒疫情下網上騙案有所增加，金管局提醒市民在網上購物或使用個人認證資料時要提高警覺，慎防詐騙圈套。

為提高年青人加入金管局工作的興趣，金管局於2020年推出公眾教育網劇《STEPS》，並在社交媒體發布一系列相關貼文，介紹金管局在貨幣、聯繫匯率制度、金融科技、普及金融、銀行監管與國際合作等範疇的工作。

公眾教育網劇《STEPS》以輕鬆的手法，透過一個新入職年青人的成長故事，介紹金管局的主要職能。

金管局在數碼平台及戶外媒體廣泛宣傳保護個人數碼鎖匙的訊息。

金管局又透過多個社區參與活動與不同持份者合作，而其中一項是網上親子理財教育活動 《小小理財師》，透過動畫影片、線上遊戲、自製玩具、可下載工作紙及填色比賽，教導幼稚園及初小學生金錢和理財的基本概念，以及有關銀行及支付服務的基本知識。

以Dollar豬和金氏一家為主角的動畫影片，就五個主題發放訊息。

示範以環保物料自製玩具。

其他有關年青人教育的工作包括網上理財問答比賽及為中學生及老師而設的網上教育講座、與一個專業團體攜手製作以小學生及家長為對象的漫畫書，以及為大專學生舉辦網上講座。

金管局支持投資者及理財教育委員會提升香港市民的金融理財知識及能力，並會研究與持份者進一步合作，提高社區參與的成效。

# 金管局員工

金管局是政府架構的一部分，但按非公務員條款聘請員工，吸引具適當經驗及專門知識的人才。金管局聘用、培訓及維持一支專業優秀的工作團隊，以履行政策目標及靈活應對工作要求的轉變。

金管局在2020年的人手編制為1,005人。年內，金管局致力透過靈活調配現有資源、提升效率及精簡工作程序，以配合新項目的需要及日益繁重的工作。金管局在2021年的人手編制將維持1,005人，並會重新調配現有資源，應付下述新開展及有所擴展的工作：

# 銀行及金融體系穩定
- 支援「理財通」的政策發展工作，以及其他粵港澳大灣區（大灣區）與私人財富管理措施，以及持續監管「理財通」業務
- 處理《保險業條例》及新的場外衍生工具制度下的發牌工作，以及有關虛擬銀行的操守監管工作
- 實施有關氣候風險的新監管規定，以及加強對銀行的審慎監管

# 儲備管理
- 加強投資、風險管理及其他必要支援，以配合外匯基金持續擴展及多元化的投資工作

# 香港的國際金融中心地位
- 為加強參與金融穩定理事會及其他國際工作小組提供支援
- 管理新近建議的附帶權益稅務寬減制度，以及核實可合資格獲稅務寬減的基金

# 薪酬福利政策及薪酬檢討機制

財政司司長透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會的意見，並參考市場薪酬水平及做法，決定金管局員工的薪酬及服務條件。薪酬組合包括現金薪酬及公積金，另設一些基本福利。現金薪酬包括每月固定薪酬（即基本薪酬）及根據員工工作表現每年一次過發放的浮動薪酬。

財政司司長每年檢討金管局員工薪酬時，會透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會的建議，並考慮管治委員會對金管局過去一年的表現評估、獨立人力資源顧問公司進行的金融業薪酬調查結果，以及其他相關因素。個別工作表現優秀的員工的薪酬亦可能獲得特別調整，以作獎勵及保持其薪酬競爭力。

金管局按個別員工的工作表現，分配獲批准用作調整年度固定薪酬及浮動薪酬的款項；而適用於負責投資的員工的浮動薪酬制度，則旨在加強其投資表現與薪酬的連繫。助理總裁及以上職級員工的固定薪酬調整及浮動薪酬的發放，是由財政司司長經參考管治委員會的意見後批准，有關員工在會議討論到其薪酬的議案時會避席。主管及以下職級員工的固定薪酬調整及浮動薪酬的發放，則由金管局總裁根據財政司司長授權，按照獲批准用作支付薪酬的整筆款項來決定。

# Organizational Functions

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) maintains effective communication with the public and the market through traditional and social media, its website, information centers, and other channels, enhancing public understanding of the HKMA’s policies and operations. Internally, the HKMA is also committed to strengthening corporate governance, including supporting staff in enhancing their professional capabilities, exercising strict financial control, strengthening information technology security, and fostering a culture of innovation to address the challenges posed by the implementation of new initiatives and an increasing workload.

# Stay Connected with the Public

# Media Relations and Social Media

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) maintains close communication with the media to enhance its transparency and foster public understanding of its policies and operations. In 2020, the HKMA held a total of 93 in-person and online events, including 8 press conferences, 5 impromptu interviews, and 80 other public events. It also arranged 14 media interviews and issued 552 bilingual press releases, in addition to handling a large volume of media inquiries daily.

To enhance public understanding of the HKMA’s core functions, the HKMA has hosted media briefings and workshops for local and overseas media, as well as key opinion leaders, covering topics such as the linked exchange rate system, financial technology, green finance, and macroprudential supervisory measures.

Hong Kong Monetary Authority Chief Executive Eddie Yue Wai-man presided over an online thematic discussion at Hong Kong Fintech Week 2020.

Hong Kong Monetary Authority Deputy Chief Executive Ruan Guohang (center) presided over a press conference to introduce the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s two-year plan to promote the application of RegTech.

Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s (HKMA) Director of Fintech, Raymond Zhou (left), accepts an interview with Bloomberg.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) utilizes social media to enhance public understanding of its work and strengthen communication with the public. It currently operates five social media pages, including Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, Twitter and YouTube. As of the end of December 2020, over 66,500 users followed the HKMA’s social media pages. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the HKMA leveraged social media to maintain contact with the public and effectively dispel misinformation related to the stability of the financial and banking systems.

# Public Inquiry / Public Queries

The public enquiry service is an effective channel for enhancing public understanding of the HKMA’s key functions and operations. It handled a total of 9,514 enquiries in 2020, with approximately half relating to banking policy and regulations, banking consumer matters, banknotes and coins, financial infrastructure and bond market development – specifically coin collection schemes, banking products and services, guidelines and announcements related to the banking sector, retail bond issuance schemes, and monetary and economic data.

Figure 1 shows the total number of public inquiries received each year since 2017, and Figure 2 lists the proportion of inquiries by category in 2020.

Figure 1: Total Number of Public Inquiries

Figure 2: Breakdown of Inquiries Received in 2020, by Nature.

# Publications

In addition to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s (HKMA) Annual Report, the HKMA published two issues of the “Monetary and Financial Stability Report” and four issues of the “Quarterly Report” during the year. It also regularly updated the data in the “Monthly Statistical Bulletin on Hong Kong’s Financial System,” providing the latest and specialized information and analysis on Hong Kong’s currency, banking sector, and economic affairs. Furthermore, the HKMA published a total of 18 articles in “HKMA Insights,” introducing the HKMA’s important measures and policies and discussing matters of public concern.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s 2019 Annual Report received a Silver Award in the “Non-profit and Charitable Organisations” category at the Hong Kong Management Association’s 2020 Best Annual Report Awards.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority Website

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s official website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides over 40,000 pages of information in English, Traditional Chinese, and Simplified Chinese, facilitating public access to the latest information from the HKMA. The website also contains the “Register of Authorized Institutions and Local Representatives” and the “Register of Authorized Institutions’ Securities Business Staff” maintained under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the “Register of Licensed Stored Value Facility Operators” maintained under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance.

Since 2018, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has been progressively releasing financial data and important information published on its website through open application programming interfaces (open APIs). By the end of 2020, the HKMA had launched a total of 144 open APIs on its website as scheduled.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority actively supports the development and application of open APIs.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority Information Centre

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority Information Centre is located on the 55th floor of International Finance Centre Tower 2, providing the public with information about the HKMA’s work and enhancing public understanding of monetary and banking matters. The Centre comprises an exhibition hall and a library. The exhibition hall introduces the work of the HKMA and the development of the monetary and banking sectors in Hong Kong through interactive displays, and also provides data and exhibits for research on Hong Kong’s currency, banking, and financial affairs. Adjacent to the exhibition hall, the library houses a collection of over 26,000 books, journals, and other publications for research on topics such as Hong Kong’s currency, banking, finance, and central banking. The library also maintains the “Register of Approved Institutions and Local Representatives’ Offices” and the “Register of Securities and Futures Professionals” as stipulated in Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority Information Centre has won a Platinum Award in the Interior Design category of the “2020 MUSE DESIGN AWARDS,” distinguished from over a thousand entrants worldwide by its carefully crafted design and unique atmosphere.

The Information Centre took advantage of the temporary closure in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic to enhance the facilities in the “Policy” exhibition area. This area explains the work of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and introduces related financial concepts. The improvements were made in response to visitor feedback, making the interactive facilities more user-friendly, engaging, and durable, thereby enhancing the overall visitor experience.

The interactive facilities in the "Policy" section of the Information Center have completed their optimization project.

The exhibition hall section of the Information Centre introduces the work of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the development of Hong Kong’s currency and banking industry.

To ensure that all members of the public, regardless of ethnicity, have equal access to the facilities of the information center, the center has established procedures to provide interpretation services for visitors who need them and for those who call the center’s hotline for inquiries.

The opening hours and services of the information center are affected by the ongoing pandemic. To ensure public safety and maintain a high level of hygiene, the information center will implement special opening arrangements and preventative measures throughout the year, with enhanced cleaning and disinfection. Facilities and exhibits will also be regularly disinfected with a long-lasting antimicrobial coating.

# Public and Consumer Education

To stay connected with the community and enhance public understanding of the HKMA’s work, the HKMA hosted an online public education session in 2020, attracting over 1,600 teachers and students from 61 secondary schools. The session covered an introduction to the HKMA’s work, the linked exchange rate system, Hong Kong banknotes, protecting personal digital keys, and the Deposit Protection Scheme. This was the first time the education session, which has been running since 1998, was held online, and to date, over 61,000 teachers and students have participated.

Over 1,600 teachers and students from 61 secondary schools participated in the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s online public education seminar.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is educating the public to be smart and responsible financial services consumers and will continue to engage with the public on this topic. A key focus of this educational work remains “Safeguarding Your Digital Keys,” and the HKMA has produced a series of short videos this year urging citizens to properly protect their financial accounts and personal information at all times and in all places. Given the increase in online scams during the COVID-19 pandemic, the HKMA reminds the public to be vigilant when shopping online or using personal identification information to avoid falling victim to fraudulent schemes.

To increase young people’s interest in working at the HKMA, the HKMA launched the public education web drama “STEPS” in 2020, and released a series of related posts on social media, introducing the HKMA’s work in areas such as currency, the linked exchange rate system, financial technology, financial inclusion, banking supervision and international cooperation.

The public education web drama *STEPS* uses a lighthearted approach to introduce the key functions of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority through the growth story of a young, newly employed individual.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has been widely promoting messages about protecting personal digital keys through digital platforms and outdoor media.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to collaborate with various stakeholders through a range of community engagement activities. One such initiative is the online financial literacy program for parents and children, “Little Financial Experts.” This program utilizes animated videos, online games, DIY toys, downloadable worksheets, and coloring contests to teach kindergarten and primary school students basic concepts about money and financial management, as well as fundamental knowledge regarding banking and payment services.

The animated video, featuring Dollar Pig and the Kim family, delivers messages on five themes.

Demonstrate making toys from environmentally friendly materials.

Other work related to youth education includes online financial literacy quizzes, online educational seminars for secondary school students and teachers, collaboration with a professional organization to produce comic books for primary school students and parents, and online seminars for tertiary students.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority supports the Investor and Financial Education Council in enhancing the financial literacy and capability of Hong Kong citizens, and will study further collaboration with stakeholders to improve the effectiveness of community engagement.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority Staff

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is part of the government structure, but employs staff under terms and conditions that are not those of civil servants, in order to attract individuals with appropriate experience and specialized knowledge. The HKMA recruits, trains, and maintains a professional and highly capable team to fulfill its policy objectives and adapt flexibly to changing job requirements.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority had a staff complement of 1,005 in 2020. Throughout the year, the HKMA strived to meet the needs of new initiatives and an increasing workload by flexibly deploying existing resources, enhancing efficiency, and streamlining work procedures. The HKMA’s staff complement will remain at 1,005 in 2021, with existing resources being redeployed to address the following newly launched and expanded work areas:

# Banking and Financial System Stability
- Support policy development for “Wealth Connect” and other Greater Bay Area (GBA) private wealth management initiatives, as well as ongoing supervision of “Wealth Connect” business.
- Handle licensing work under the Insurance Ordinance and the new over-the-counter derivatives regime, and conduct ethical supervision of virtual banks.
- Implement new regulatory requirements regarding climate risks and strengthen prudential supervision of banks.

# Reserve Management
- Strengthen investment, risk management, and other necessary support to align with the continued expansion and diversification of foreign exchange fund investment operations.

# Hong Kong’s Status as an International Financial Centre
- To strengthen support for participation in the Financial Stability Board and other international working groups
- To administer the recently proposed deemed benefit tax concession scheme and verify funds eligible for tax concessions

Table 1 lists the establishment of positions and the actual number of staff at the HKMA by department.

Table 1: HKMA Establishment and Actual Staff Numbers as of January 1, 2021

# Compensation and Benefits Policy and Salary Review Mechanism

The Financial Secretary, through the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, receives input from its subordinate governance committees and, with reference to market compensation levels and practices, determines the salary and terms of service for Hong Kong Monetary Authority staff. The compensation package includes cash compensation and mandatory provident fund contributions, along with a range of basic benefits. Cash compensation comprises a fixed monthly salary (i.e., basic salary) and a variable pay component awarded annually based on employee performance.

The Financial Secretary reviews the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s (HKMA) staff remuneration annually, consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee to obtain advice from its governance committee. This review considers the governance committee’s assessment of the HKMA’s performance over the past year, the results of remuneration surveys for the financial industry conducted by independent human resources consulting firms, and other relevant factors. The remuneration of individual employees with outstanding performance may also be subject to special adjustments as a reward and to maintain its competitiveness.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority allocates funds approved for adjusting annual fixed and variable compensation based on individual employee performance. The variable compensation scheme applicable to employees responsible for investment is designed to strengthen the link between their investment performance and remuneration. Adjustments to the fixed compensation and disbursement of variable compensation for Assistant General Manager and above are approved by the Financial Secretary after considering the views of the Governance Committee, and these employees recuse themselves from discussions on their own compensation proposals at meetings. Adjustments to the fixed compensation and disbursement of variable compensation for staff at the Manager level and below are determined by the Chief Executive of the HKMA, in accordance with the overall funds approved for salary payments, under the authorization of the Financial Secretary.

# 機構社會責任

金管局致力履行機構社會責任，以成為負責任及可持續發展的機構為目標。金管局在不同領域履行此承諾，包括推動可持續發展及具環保意識的市場、關懷廣大社會、保護環境及締造友善的工作環境。

為應對新冠病毒疫情，金管局推出多項措施，支援有需要的個人及企業，從而協助香港經濟渡過難關。

# 市場環境

# 綠色及可持續金融

氣候變化是影響人類福祉及全球經濟可持續性的主要風險之一，作為社會重要環節之一的金融體系，亦難免會受到影響；而銀行作為金融體系的一部分，應更積極管理氣候風險。有見及此，金管局致力探究應對這項挑戰的方法，並正落實多項於2019年5月宣布推出的措施，促進綠色金融在香港的發展。有關措施包括分三階段推動綠色及可持續銀行業的發展：

# 第一階段

與業界建立一個共同框架，評估銀行目前的「綠色基準」，以及與國際組織合作，為本港銀行提供技術支援；

# 第二階段

就綠色及可持續銀行業的監管期望及要求諮詢業界及其他持份者；以及

# 第三階段

集中落實、審視及評估銀行在這方面的進度。

在國際層面，金管局參與多個國際組織，包括央行與監管機構綠色金融網絡、巴塞爾銀行監管委員會轄下的氣候相關財務風險高級別工作組、東亞及太平洋地區中央銀行會議轄下銀行監管工作小組之下的可持續金融關注組及國際可持續金融平台。透過參與這些國際組織，金管局有機會為中央銀行界及監管機構在應對氣候變化的工作上作出貢獻，並能在制定本地架構時借鑑其他地區的經驗與觀點。

金管局亦參與央行與監管機構綠色金融網絡下的多個工作組，包括微觀審慎監管工作組、宏觀金融工作組及促進綠色金融工作組。此外，金管局亦加入了兩個新設的工作組：研究工作組及彌補數據缺口工作組。研究工作組負責相關研究工作，而彌補數據缺口工作組旨在制定監管當局及金融機構評估氣候相關風險與機遇所需、但目前卻並未掌握的數據項目詳盡清單。有關金管局年內在推動綠色及可持續銀行業發展方面的工作，詳見「銀行體系穩定」一章。

金管局在11月與國際金融公司聯合推出綠色商業銀行聯盟，協助各新興市場的銀行制定應對氣候變化的方案。作為聯盟的創始成員及首個區域執行理事，金管局i)在全球金融市場推動發展綠色商業銀行；ii)為商業銀行提供互相學習平台，獲取所需知識、工具及商業資訊，以制定其本身的綠色金融路線圖，並轉型為具公信力的綠色銀行；iii)促進溝通，並探討前沿議題推動全球綠色議程；以及iv)協助聯盟的成員合作，以及把握國際金融公司所識別在未來10年估計高達23萬億美元的新興市場綠色及氣候相關投資機會。

本地方面，金管局與其他金融監管機構合作，協調金融業針對氣候和環境風險的措施應對。除了協助政府落實政府綠色債券計劃的相關工作外，金管局亦與證券及期貨事務監察委員會（證監會）共同發起成立了綠色和可持續金融跨機構督導小組（督導小組），處理跨行業的監管及市場發展事宜。有關金管局年內在發展香港成為綠色及可持續金融樞紐方面的工作，詳見「香港的國際金融中心地位」一章。

# 綠色和可持續金融跨機構督導小組

督導小組旨在協調金融業針對氣候及環境風險的措施應對、加快香港綠色及可持續金融的發展，以及支持政府的氣候策略。督導小組由金管局與證監會於5月共同發起成立，其他成員包括環境局、財經事務及庫務局、香港交易及結算所有限公司、保險業監管局及強制性公積金計劃管理局。

自成立以來，督導小組設立了兩個技術工作專責團隊，分別負責研究及處理跨部門的監管事宜，以及協調跨機構的市場發展工作。

督導小組在12月發布綠色及可持續金融策略，提出從六方面鞏固香港金融生態系統，長遠共建更綠色及更可持續的未來。督導小組亦宣布5個短期行動綱領，處理發展過程中一些最迫切的問題。

金管局舉辦督導小組成立大會，金管局總裁余偉文先生（右三）為該小組的聯席主席。

督導小組發布香港的綠色和可持續金融策略計劃及5個主要行動綱領。

# 負責任投資

金管局支持負責任投資，即將環境、社會及管治(ESG)因素融入投資活動中。金管局作為規模龐大的資產擁有人，日益關注負責任投資，將對其基金經理如何進行投資活動產生影響。

# 金管局的信念

金管局相信透過適度強調負責任投資及考慮各項投資的可持續長期表現，將更有效達致外匯基金的投資目標，並且減低投資活動所涉及的ESG相關風險。

# 金管局的原則

按金管局採取的指導性原則，當ESG投資與其他投資項目的經風險調整長期收益相若時，一般會優先考慮ESG投資。作為負責任的長期投資者，金管局在投資管理過程中，會因應情況採納以下的負責任投資原則：

# 融入

金管局相信ESG因素會對投資項目的長期價值帶來重大影響，因此將ESG因素融入投資分析程序，以辨察風險及物色良機。金管局將ESG因素併入公開市場及私募市場的投資管理過程中。

# 主動行使資產擁有權

金管局就所持有的上市公司股票適當地行使股東權利，以維護投資的長期價值。金管局相信，顧及ESG因素的負責任企業行為，將有助創造長綫的股東利益。金管局期望外聘投資經理透過行使表決權及與獲投資公司溝通時，主動行使資產擁有權，藉以協助金管局履行對投資項目的擁有權責任。

# 合作

金管局致力與理念相近的投資者及監管機構合作，推動良好的長期投資管理手法，又出席公開活動並發表演講，分享更完善的ESG作業手法及鼓勵投資界採納負責任投資理念。

有關金管局年內在負責任投資方面的工作，詳見「儲備管理」一章。

# 金管局作為主動的負責任投資者，監察外聘投資經理的ESG作業手法

# 金管局的期望

金管局非常重視將ESG因素融入投資決定及主動行使資產擁有權等概念。為此，金管局在甄選聘任及監察外聘投資經理時，皆會考慮ESG因素。由於金管局認為就所持有的上市公司股票行使股東權利，是維護投資的長期價值的基本方針，因此會要求獲聘任的投資經理嚴肅對待主動行使資產擁有權一事。

# 金管局的監察

外聘投資經理須就其替金管局管理的上市股票組合的ESG表現接受評估。金管局透過溝通計劃，有系統地檢視外聘投資經理在不同範疇的ESG作業手法，例如其ESG評估架構、與獲投資公司的溝通，以及代理投票方面的工作。金管局在2020年選出若干外聘投資經理率先進行溝通計劃，當中不僅評估其ESG表現，亦檢視其有否代表金管局妥善行使資產擁有權。

# 溝通成果

金管局透過計劃識別出作業手法有問題的外聘投資經理，並採取跟進行動。下文列舉其中兩個例子。

# 個案1

金管局留意到股票投資經理A的ESG架構有改善空間，尤其應設立更有系統的方法去評估獲投資公司。金管局就此與A跟進，其後A進行全面的公司政策檢討，以實施一個更穩健的ESG架構。A更特別委任外聘顧問就ESG程序提供意見，反映加快落實改革的決心，並新設由高級管理層組成的ESG委員會，顯示對ESG的承擔及高級管理層對有關措施的支持。

# 個案2

金管局在檢視股票投資經理B的投票方法後，發現B的投票政策在多個範疇上都有不足之處，並要求其ESG主管作出審視。尤其B在過往的投票全數贊成管理層的建議，偏離其本身的代理投票指引。B其後承諾會加強公司的投票政策以符合期望，其中包括會提高ESG團隊成員的參與度，以及在遇上涉及重大管治問題時有可能對管理層投下反對票。

在私募市場投資方面，金管局藉着其專責合夥人致力與相關投資組合公司在ESG事宜上合作，從而實現負責任投資。金管局留意到專責合夥人都貫徹對ESG的承擔，因他們認為此舉可有利創造投資組合公司的長期價值和確保回報的可持續性。下文列舉的兩個例子顯示可透過(i)設計改動及利用創新運作技術；以及(ii)在建造及營運綠色及可持續倉庫時融入減碳因素，以管理氣候變化風險。兩個例子都對環境產生顯著的正面影響，減少碳排放，避免有害物質，並同時透過降低成本及節省能源，提升運作效率。

(i) 金管局有投資一間採用環保方案的害蟲防治公司。雖然傳統殺蟲劑及化學製品能有效殺滅害蟲，但若未能迅速清除或妥善棄置蟲屍，將會危害公共衛生。此外，化學成分的滲漏及棄置亦會造成環境問題。該公司採用的不含生物殺滅劑方案，透過設置捕蟲器以減少使用有害化學品。該公司亦利用與互聯網相連的動態感應器，遙距偵察是否已捕獲害蟲。藉着此項新技術，該公司能作出完善的路線規劃以收集捕獲的害蟲，減低出行里程，從而減少碳排放。該公司採用的方案令公司整體碳排的淨效應達到每美元淨銷售額0.36千克二氧化碳當量的低水平，接近法律服務及軟件出版等低碳行業的平均水平，實在令人鼓舞。

(ii) 金管局有投資綠色及可持續倉庫。雖然建造業是碳排放的一大源頭，但有關的倉庫發展商在其整體倉庫建造與營運中，採用淨零碳排放程序，並制定衡量淨零碳排放基準的標準及指標，而建築計劃亦顧及所用材料與部件的可持續性。因此，所建造的倉庫減碳效率高，並具備可持續特點，包括太陽能加熱系統、電動車充電設施、自然採光及雨水收集等。

根據獨立顧問的評估，按淨額計，有關倉庫建造的碳足跡較一般物流大廈的碳排放量低25.8%。為進一步抵銷建築工程所造成的碳排放，建造過程中更種植了32,799棵樹（以淨額計）。建成後倉庫的日常運作的碳排放量較一般倉庫少26.9%。

# Institutional Social Responsibility

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is committed to fulfilling its corporate social responsibility, with the goal of becoming a responsible and sustainable institution. The HKMA demonstrates this commitment in various areas, including promoting sustainable development and environmentally conscious markets, caring for the wider community, protecting the environment, and creating a friendly working environment.

To address the COVID-19 pandemic, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has launched a series of measures to support individuals and businesses in need, thereby helping the Hong Kong economy navigate these challenging times.

# Market Environment

# Green and Sustainable Finance

Climate change is one of the major risks impacting human well-being and the sustainability of the global economy, and the financial system, as an important component of society, is inevitably affected. As part of the financial system, banks should more proactively manage climate-related risks. In light of this, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is committed to exploring ways to address this challenge and is implementing a number of measures announced in May 2019 to promote the development of green finance in Hong Kong. These measures include promoting the development of green and sustainable banking in three phases:

# Phase One

Establish a common framework with the industry to assess the current “green benchmarks” of banks, and collaborate with international organizations to provide technical support to banks in Hong Kong.

# Phase Two

Consulting the industry and other stakeholders on regulatory expectations and requirements for green and sustainable banking; and

# Phase Three

Focus on implementing, reviewing, and evaluating the bank’s progress in this regard.

At the international level, the HKMA participates in a number of international organizations, including the Network for Greening the Financial System (NGFS), the Climate-related Financial Risks High-Level Work Stream under the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision, the Sustainable Finance Focus Group under the Banking Supervision Committee of the East Asia and Pacific Central Banks (EAPCB), and the International Sustainable Finance Platform. Through participation in these organizations, the HKMA has the opportunity to contribute to the work of central banks and regulators in addressing climate change, and to draw on the experiences and perspectives of other jurisdictions when developing the local framework.

The HKMA also participates in several working groups under the Central Banks and Supervisors Network for Greening the Financial System (NGFS), including the Microprudential Supervision Group, the Macrofinancial Group, and the Green Finance Group. In addition, the HKMA has joined two newly established working groups: the Research Group and the Data Gap Filling Group. The Research Group is responsible for related research work, while the Data Gap Filling Group aims to develop a detailed list of data items required by regulators and financial institutions to assess climate-related risks and opportunities, but which are currently unavailable. Details of the HKMA’s work this year in promoting the development of green and sustainable banking are set out in the chapter on “Financial System Stability”.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) jointly launched the Green Banking Alliance with the International Finance Corporation in November to help banks in emerging markets develop strategies to address climate change. As a founding member and the first regional executive council, the HKMA will i) promote the development of green banking in global financial markets; ii) provide a platform for commercial banks to learn from each other and acquire the knowledge, tools, and business information needed to formulate their own green finance roadmaps and transform into credible green banks; iii) facilitate communication and explore cutting-edge issues to advance the global green agenda; and iv) assist members of the Alliance in collaborating and capitalizing on emerging market green and climate-related investment opportunities identified by the International Finance Corporation, estimated at up to US$23 trillion over the next 10 years.

Locally, the HKMA is collaborating with other financial regulators to coordinate the financial industry’s response to climate and environmental risks. In addition to assisting the Government in implementing its green bond program, the HKMA has also jointly established the Cross-Agency Steering Group on Green and Sustainable Finance (Steering Group) with the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) to address cross-sectoral regulatory and market development matters. Details of the HKMA’s work this year on developing Hong Kong as a green and sustainable finance hub can be found in the chapter “Hong Kong’s Status as an International Financial Centre.”

# Green and Sustainable Finance Cross-Agency Steering Committee

The Steering Group aims to coordinate the financial industry’s response to climate and environmental risks, accelerate the development of green and sustainable finance in Hong Kong, and support the government’s climate strategies. Jointly launched by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Securities and Futures Commission in May, the Steering Group also includes representatives from the Environment Bureau, the Financial Services and the Treasury Bureau, Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited, the Insurance Authority, and the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority.

Since its establishment, the steering committee has set up two dedicated technical working groups, one responsible for researching and handling cross-departmental regulatory matters, and the other for coordinating market development work across institutions.

The Steering Group released the Green and Sustainable Finance Strategy in December, outlining six areas to strengthen Hong Kong’s financial ecosystem and collaboratively build a greener and more sustainable future in the long run. The Steering Group also announced five short-term action plans to address some of the most pressing issues in the development process.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) held the inaugural meeting of its supervisory committee, with HKMA Chief Executive Eddie Yue (third from right) serving as a co-chairperson of the committee.

The Steering Group has released Hong Kong’s Green and Sustainable Finance Strategy and five key action plans.

# Responsible Investment

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority supports responsible investment, integrating environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors into its investment activities. As a large-scale asset owner, the HKMA is increasingly focused on responsible investment, which will impact how its fund managers conduct their investment activities.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Beliefs

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority believes that by appropriately emphasizing responsible investment and considering the sustainable long-term performance of various investments, it will more effectively achieve the investment objectives of the Exchange Fund and mitigate ESG-related risks associated with investment activities.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Principles

In line with the guiding principles adopted by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, ESG investments are generally prioritized when their risk-adjusted long-term returns are comparable to those of other investment options. As a responsible long-term investor, the HKMA incorporates the following responsible investment principles into its investment management process as appropriate.

# Integration

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority believes that ESG factors will have a significant impact on the long-term value of investment projects, and therefore incorporates ESG factors into its investment analysis procedures to identify risks and opportunities. The HKMA integrates ESG factors into its investment management processes for both public and private markets.

# Active exercise of asset ownership rights.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority appropriately exercises shareholder rights in listed companies it holds shares in, to safeguard the long-term value of its investments. The HKMA believes that responsible corporate behaviour considering ESG factors will contribute to long-term shareholder interests. The HKMA expects external investment managers to proactively exercise ownership, through the exercise of voting rights and communication with investee companies, to assist the HKMA in fulfilling its ownership responsibilities with respect to its investments.

# Cooperation

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is committed to collaborating with like-minded investors and regulators to promote sound long-term investment practices, and participates in public events and delivers speeches to share best practices in ESG operations and encourage the investment community to adopt responsible investment principles.

Details regarding the HKMA’s work on responsible investment within the year can be found in the “Reserve Management” chapter.

# The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, as an active and responsible investor, monitors the ESG practices of its external investment managers.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s Expectations

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority places great importance on incorporating ESG factors into investment decisions and proactively exercising ownership rights. To this end, the HKMA considers ESG factors when selecting, appointing, and monitoring external investment managers. As the HKMA believes that exercising shareholder rights in listed companies it holds is fundamental to preserving the long-term value of its investments, it requires appointed investment managers to take the proactive exercise of ownership rights seriously.

# The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Supervision.

Externally hired investment managers must be assessed on the ESG performance of the listed equity portfolios they manage for the HKMA. The HKMA systematically reviews the ESG practices of externally hired investment managers in different areas through a communication program, such as their ESG assessment frameworks, communication with investee companies, and proxy voting work. In 2020, the HKMA selected a number of externally hired investment managers to pilot the communication program, which not only assessed their ESG performance but also reviewed whether they had properly exercised ownership rights on behalf of the HKMA.

# Communication outcomes / Results of communication / Communication achievements

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority identified outsourced investment managers with problematic operational practices through its review process and took follow-up actions. The following are two examples.

# Case 1

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority noted that there was room for improvement in the ESG framework of fund manager A, particularly regarding the establishment of a more systematic approach to assessing investee companies. The HKMA followed up with A on this matter, after which A conducted a comprehensive review of its company policies to implement a more robust ESG framework. A specifically appointed external consultants to provide advice on ESG procedures, reflecting a commitment to accelerating the implementation of reforms, and established a new ESG committee comprised of senior management, demonstrating its commitment to ESG and the support of senior management for the related measures.

# Case 2

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, after reviewing the voting methods of stock investment manager B, found deficiencies in B’s voting policies in several areas and has requested its ESG head to conduct a review. Specifically, B had previously voted in favor of management’s proposals in all instances, deviating from its own proxy voting guidelines. B subsequently committed to strengthening the company’s voting policies to meet expectations, including increasing the involvement of ESG team members and potentially voting against management in cases involving significant governance issues.

In the realm of private market investments, the HKMA collaborates with its dedicated fund managers on ESG matters to achieve responsible investing. The HKMA has noted the consistent commitment of these dedicated fund managers to ESG, as they believe it can contribute to the long-term value creation and ensure the sustainability of returns for portfolio companies. The following two examples demonstrate how climate change risks can be managed through (i) design modifications and the utilization of innovative operating technologies; and (ii) incorporating decarbonization factors when constructing and operating green and sustainable warehouses. Both examples have a significant positive impact on the environment, reducing carbon emissions, avoiding harmful substances, and simultaneously improving operational efficiency through cost reduction and energy conservation.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has invested in a pest control company that employs environmentally friendly solutions. While traditional pesticides and chemical products can effectively kill pests, failure to promptly remove or properly dispose of carcasses can pose a threat to public health. Furthermore, leakage and disposal of chemical components can cause environmental problems. The company’s approach utilizes non-biocidal pest control methods, employing traps to reduce the use of harmful chemicals. It also uses internet-connected dynamic sensors to remotely monitor pest capture rates. This new technology allows the company to optimize collection routes for captured pests, reducing travel distances and thereby lowering carbon emissions. The company’s solution results in a net carbon footprint of just 0.36 kilograms of carbon dioxide equivalent per dollar of net sales, a low level comparable to low-carbon industries such as legal services and software publishing – a truly encouraging result.

(ii) The HKMA invests in green and sustainable warehouses. While the construction industry is a major source of carbon emissions, the warehouse developers involved employ net-zero carbon procedures throughout the construction and operation of their warehouses, and have established standards and metrics to measure net-zero carbon emissions. Furthermore, building plans consider the sustainability of materials and components used. Consequently, the constructed warehouses are highly carbon-efficient and possess sustainable features, including solar water heating systems, electric vehicle charging facilities, natural lighting, and rainwater harvesting.

According to an independent assessment, the carbon footprint of the warehouse, measured on a net basis, is 25.8% lower than the carbon emissions of a typical logistics building. To further offset the carbon emissions generated during construction, 32,799 trees were planted throughout the building process (on a net basis). Once completed, the warehouse’s day-to-day operational carbon emissions are 26.9% lower than those of a standard warehouse.

# 獨立審計師報告致財政司司長

# 意見

茲證明我已審計列載於第187至289頁外匯基金及其附屬公司（「集團」）的財務報表，該等財務報表包括外匯基金及集團於2020年12月31日的資產負債表與截至該日止年度的收支帳目、全面收益表、權益變動表和現金流量表，以及財務報表的附註，包括主要會計政策概要。

我認為，該等財務報表已按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》真實而中肯地反映外匯基金及集團於2020年12月31日的財務狀況及截至該日止年度的財務表現和現金流量，並已按照行政長官在《外匯基金條例》（第66章）第7條下所發出的指示妥為擬備。

# 意見的基礎
